claim: Progressive overload—gradually increasing training volume, intensity, or load—is necessary to stimulate muscle growth over time.
Training each muscle group with 10–20 weekly sets is associated with greater hypertrophy in trained individuals.
source: Journal of Strength and Conditioning Research

claim: For maximizing muscle hypertrophy, daily protein intake of approximately 1.6–2.2 grams per kilogram of body weight is recommended for resistance-trained individuals.
evidence: Systematic review and meta-analysis of resistance training studies

claim: Distributing protein intake evenly across meals (20–40 g per meal) supports muscle protein synthesis throughout the day.
evidence: Controlled feeding trials in healthy adults

claim: A back and biceps bro split emphasizing vertical and horizontal pulling maximizes hypertrophy when volume is sufficient and sets are taken close to failure.
evidence: Back and biceps hypertrophy is optimized through compound pulling movements, varied angles, and proximity to muscular failure with adequate rest intervals.
source: Journal of Strength and Conditioning Research

exercises.name: Barbell Bench Press
exercises.notes: Focus on controlled eccentric and full range of motion.

exercises.name: Incline Dumbbell Press
exercises.notes: Emphasize upper chest; stop 1 rep before form breakdown.

exercises.name: Cable Fly
exercises.notes: Constt tension; slow squeeze at peak contraction.

exercises.name: Triceps Pushdown
exercises.notes: Elbows locked in; avoid shoulder movement.

claim: A shoulder-focused workout emphasizing overhead pressing and lateral raises maximizes deltoid hypertrophy when sets are taken close to failure.
evidence: Shoulder hypertrophy is driven by sufficient pressing volume and lateral raise variations performed near muscular failure with controlled tempo.
source: Journal of Strength and Conditioning Research

claim: Exercise and nutrition strategies should not be presented as treatments or cures for cancer, which requires medical diagnosis and treatment by qualified healthcare professionals.
Adequate sleep (7–9 hours per night) supports muscle recovery and growth by regulating anabolic hormones such as growth hormone and testosterone.
evidence: Sleep deprivation and hormonal regulation studies
